message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The Safety Filter: A Unified View of Safety-Critical Control in Autonomous Systems
Paper Abstract: Recent years have seen significant progress in the realm of robot autonomy, accompanied by the expanding reach of robotic technologies. However, the emergence of new deployment domains brings unprecedented challenges in ensuring safe operation of these systems, which remains as crucial as ever. While traditional model-based safe control methods struggle with generalizability and scalability, emerging data-driven approaches tend to lack well-understood guarantees, which can result in unpredictable catastrophic failures. Successful deployment of the next generation of autonomous robots will require integrating the strengths of both paradigms. This article provides a review of safety filter approaches, highlighting important connections between existing techniques and proposing a unified technical framework to understand, compare, and combine them. The new unified view exposes a shared modular structure across a range of seemingly disparate safety filter classes and naturally suggests directions for future progress toward more scalable synthesis, robust monitoring, and efficient intervention.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed the web search for "Autonomous Systems". The search results returned several different interpretations of the term, as it's used across multiple fields:

## Main Meanings:

1. **Internet/Networking Context**: An autonomous system (AS) is a collection of connected Internet Protocol (IP) routing prefixes under the control of one or more network operators on behalf of a single administrative entity or domain, that presents a common and clearly defined routing policy to the Internet.

2. **Artificial Intelligence/Agents**: An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.

3. **Robotics**: The most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation. Systems such as Motivity can rely on different sensors in different areas, depending upon which provides the most reliable data at the time, and can re-map a building autonomously.

4. **Mathematics**: In mathematics, an autonomous system or autonomous differential equation is a system of ordinary differential equations which does not explicitly depend on the independent variable.

5. **Decentralized Systems**: An autonomous decentralized system (or ADS) is a decentralized system composed of modules or components that are designed to operate independently but are capable of interacting with each other to meet the overall goal of the system.

The term "autonomous systems" is broad and can refer to different concepts depending on the field of study or application.

Web search results for query: "Machine Learning Control"

Links: [{"title":"Machine learning control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning_control"},{"title":"Robot learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Hyperparameter (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperparameter_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Data version control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_version_control"},{"title":"Information engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_engineering_(field)"},{"title":"Robotic arm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_arm"},{"title":"Raja Chatila - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raja_Chatila"},{"title":"Incremental learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incremental_learning"},{"title":"Cybernetics: Or Control and Communication in the Animal and the Machine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cybernetics:_Or_Control_and_Communication_in_the_Animal_and_the_Machine"}]

Here are the search results for "Machine Learning Control":

## Overview

Machine learning control (MLC) is a subfield of machine learning, intelligent control, and control theory which aims to solve optimal control problems with machine learning methods.(no content)Key applications are complex nonlinear systems for which linear control theory methods are not applicable.

## Key Approaches

**Reinforcement Learning Control:**
The control law may be continually updated over measured performance changes (rewards) using reinforcement learning.

**Adaptive Dynamic Programming:**
Adaptive Dynamic Programming (ADP), also known as approximate dynamic programming or neuro-dynamic programming, is a machine learning control method that combines reinforcement learning with dynamic programming to solve optimal control problems for complex systems.(no content)ADP addresses the "curse of dimensionality" in traditional dynamic programming by approximating value functions or control policies using parametric structures such as neural networks.

## Applications

ADP has been applied to robotics, power systems, and autonomous vehicles, offering a data-driven framework for near-optimal control without requiring full system models. Additionally, reinforcement learning has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.

## Challenges

Challenges remain in ensuring stability guarantees and convergence for general nonlinear systems.

Web search results for query: "Robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics"},{"title":"VEX Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VEX_Robotics"},{"title":"List of robotics companies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_robotics_companies"},{"title":"Laws of robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laws_of_robotics"},{"title":"Soft robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soft_robotics"},{"title":"Hexapod (robotics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hexapod_(robotics)"},{"title":"Hanson Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hanson_Robotics"},{"title":"Horizon Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horizon_Robotics"},{"title":"Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot"},{"title":"Robotic arm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_arm"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of robotics based on the search results:

## Definition and Scope

Robotics is the interdisciplinary study and practice of the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.(no content)A robot is a machine—especially one programmable by a computer—capable of carrying out a complex series of actions automatically.

## Key Components of Robotics

Robotics typically combines three main design elements:

1. **Mechanical Construction**: A frame, form or shape designed to achieve a particular task.

2. **Electrical Systems**: Electrical components are used for movement (through motors), sensing (where electrical signals are used to measure things like heat, sound, position, and energy status), and operation.

3. **Software**: A program is how a robot decides when or how to do something.

## Specialized Fields

**Soft Robotics**: Soft robotics is a subfield of robotics that concerns the design, control, and fabrication of robots composed of compliant materials, instead of rigid links.(no content)In contrast to rigid-bodied robots built from metals, ceramics and hard plastics, the compliance of soft robots can improve their safety when working in close contact with humans.

**Robotic Arms**: A robotic arm is a type of mechanical arm, usually programmable, with similar functions to a human arm.

## Industry Trends

In the 21st century, investment in robotics companies has grown due to increasing demand for automation.

**Soft Robotics**: Soft robotics is a subfield of robotics that concerns the design, control, and fabrication of robots composed of compliant materials, instead of rigid links.(no content)In contrast to rigid-bodied robots built from metals, ceramics and hard plastics, the compliance of soft robots can improve their safety when working in close contact with humans.

**Robotic Arms**: A robotic arm is a type of mechanical arm, usually programmable, with similar functions to a human arm.

## Industry Trends

In the 21st century, investment in robotics companies has grown due to increasing demand for automation.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Robot Autonomy:

## Definition

An autonomous robot is a robot that acts without recourse to human control. More formally, robots require "a degree of autonomy", which is the "ability to perform intended tasks based on current state and sensing, without human intervention".

## Examples

Historic examples include space probes, while modern examples include self-driving vacuums and cars. Additional examples include Amazon's Astro for home monitoring, security and eldercare in September 2021, and Starship Technologies, which by June 2023 had completed over 5 million commercial autonomous deliveries with their fleet of 2,000 autonomous robots.

## Key Capabilities

**Sensing and Perception**: Autonomous robots must have a range of environmental sensors to perform their task and stay out of trouble.(no content)The most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation.

**Navigation**: Current commercial robots autonomously navigate based on sensing natural features.(no content)Some utilize cameras or LiDAR sensors to map indoor routes and determine their position using SLAM (Simultaneous Localization and Mapping).

**AI and Learning**: Machine learning techniques, particularly reinforcement learning and deep learning, allow robots to improve their performance over time through AI models that enable robots to learn from their experiences, which is particularly useful in environments where pre-programmed behavior is insufficient, such as in search and rescue missions or unpredictable industrial tasks.

## Levels of Autonomy

For service robots, autonomy ranges from partial autonomy including human-robot interaction to full autonomy without active human robot intervention.

Web search results for query: "Safety-Critical Control"

Links: [{"title":"Safety-critical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safety-critical_system"},{"title":"Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hazard_Analysis_Critical_Control_Point"},{"title":"Critical control point - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_control_point"},{"title":"Mission critical - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mission_critical"},{"title":"Hazard analysis and risk-based preventive controls - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hazard_analysis_and_risk-based_preventive_controls"},{"title":"GE Measurement & Control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GE_Measurement_&_Control"},{"title":"Fish processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fish_processing"},{"title":"Beach Head II: The Dictator Strikes Back - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beach_Head_II:_The_Dictator_Strikes_Back"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Safety-Critical Control:

## Safety-Critical Systems Overview

A safety-critical system is designed to lose less than one life per billion (10⁹) hours of operation.(no content)The key difference between a safety critical system and mission critical system is that a safety critical system is a system that, if it fails, may result in serious environmental damage, injury, or loss of life, while a mission critical system may result in failure in goal-directed activity.

## Design and Implementation

Typical design methods include probabilistic risk assessment, a method that combines failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA) with fault tree analysis.(no content)Safety-critical systems are increasingly computer-based.

## Types of Safety System Approaches

Safety-critical systems employ different reliability regimes:

- Fail-operational systems continue to operate when their control systems fail, with examples including elevators, gas thermostats in home furnaces, and passively safe nuclear reactors.

- Fail-soft systems are able to continue operating on an interim basis with reduced efficiency in case of failure.

- Fault-tolerant systems avoid service failure when faults are introduced to the system, with the normal method to tolerate faults being to have several computers continually test the parts of a system and switch on hot spares for failing subsystems.

- Fail-safe systems become safe when they cannot operate, with many medical systems falling into this category—for example, an infusion pump can fail, and as long as it alerts the nurse and ceases pumping, it will not threaten loss of life.

Links: [{"title":"Data-driven model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data-driven_model"},{"title":"Story-driven modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Story-driven_modeling"},{"title":"Metamodeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metamodeling"},{"title":"Space Weather Modeling Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Weather_Modeling_Framework"},{"title":"Agent-based computational economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-Based_Computational_Economics"},{"title":"Content-oriented workflow models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Content-oriented_workflow_models"},{"title":"Data - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data-driven"},{"title":"Domain driven data mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain_driven_data_mining"},{"title":"Rational unified process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Process_Driven_Development"},{"title":"Feature-driven development - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feature-driven_development"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of Data-driven Modeling:

## Definition

Data-driven models are a class of computational models that primarily rely on historical data collected throughout a system's or process' lifetime to establish relationships between input, internal, and output variables.

## Overview

Data-driven models encompass a wide range of techniques and methodologies that aim to intelligently process and analyse large datasets.(no content)The term "data-driven modelling" (DDM) refers to the overarching paradigm of using historical data in conjunction with advanced computational techniques, including machine learning and artificial intelligence, to create models that can reveal underlying trends, patterns, and, in some cases, make predictions.

## Evolution

Data-driven models have evolved from earlier statistical models, overcoming limitations posed by strict assumptions about probability distributions.(no content)These models have gained prominence across various fields, particularly in the era of big data, artificial intelligence, and machine learning, where they offer valuable insights and predictions based on the available data.

## Techniques and Applications

Examples include fuzzy logic, fuzzy and rough sets for handling uncertainty, neural networks for approximating functions, global optimization and evolutionary computing, statistical learning theory, and Bayesian methods.(no content)These models have found applications in various fields, including economics, customer relations management, financial services, medicine, and the military, among others.

## Advantages

Data-driven models can be built with or without detailed knowledge of the underlying processes governing the system behavior, which makes them particularly useful when such knowledge is missing or fragmented.

Data-driven models encompass a wide range of techniques and methodologies that aim to intelligently process and analyse large datasets.(no content)The term "data-driven modelling" (DDM) refers to the overarching paradigm of using historical data in conjunction with advanced computational techniques, including machine learning and artificial intelligence, to create models that can reveal underlying trends, patterns, and, in some cases, make predictions.

## Evolution

Data-driven models have evolved from earlier statistical models, overcoming limitations posed by strict assumptions about probability distributions.(no content)These models have gained prominence across various fields, particularly in the era of big data, artificial intelligence, and machine learning, where they offer valuable insights and predictions based on the available data.

## Techniques and Applications

Examples include fuzzy logic, fuzzy and rough sets for handling uncertainty, neural networks for approximating functions, global optimization and evolutionary computing, statistical learning theory, and Bayesian methods.(no content)These models have found applications in various fields, including economics, customer relations management, financial services, medicine, and the military, among others.

## Advantages

Data-driven models can be built with or without detailed knowledge of the underlying processes governing the system behavior, which makes them particularly useful when such knowledge is missing or fragmented.

Here are the key results from the search on "Safety Verification":

## Overview

Verification and validation are independent procedures used together for checking that a product, service, or system meets requirements and specifications and that it fulfills its intended purpose.

## Software Safety Verification

Independent Software Verification and Validation (ISVV) is targeted at safety-critical software systems and aims to increase the quality of software products, thereby reducing risks and costs throughout the operational life of the software.(no content)The goal of ISVV is to provide assurance that software performs to the specified level of confidence and within its designed parameters and defined requirements.

## System Safety Verification

Modern system safety is comprehensive and is risk based, requirements based, functional based and criteria based with goal structured objectives to yield engineering evidence to verify safety functionality is deterministic and acceptable risk in the intended operating environment.(no content)Software with safety-critical functionality must be thoroughly verified with objective analysis and preferably test evidence that all safety requirements have been met per established criteria.

## Safety Instrumented Systems

For critical industrial applications, the SIL requirements are verified during the design, construction, installation, and operation of the SIS, and the required functionality may be verified by design reviews, factory acceptance testing, site acceptance testing, and regular functional testing.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Control Theory"

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Perceptual control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptual_control_theory"},{"title":"Social control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_control_theory"},{"title":"Control theory (sociology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory_(sociology)"},{"title":"Affect control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_control_theory"},{"title":"Closed system (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed_system_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Classical control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_control_theory"},{"title":"Compensator (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compensator_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"}]

Here are the search results for "Control Theory":

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, or SP-PV error, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)Although the most direct application of mathematical control theory is its use in control systems engineering, control theory is routinely applied to problems both the natural and behavioral sciences. As the general theory of feedback systems, control theory is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

## Historical Background

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Search Results: Safety Filter Control Systems

The web search returned results covering several types of systems related to safety and filtering:

### Safety Instrumented Systems (SIS)

An SIS is intended to perform specific control functions to prevent unsafe process operations when unacceptable or dangerous conditions occur.(no content)An SIS is composed of the same types of control elements (including sensors, logic solvers, actuators and other control equipment) as a Basic Process Control System (BPCS).(no content)One example of SIS is a temperature sensor that provides a signal to a controller, which compares the sensed process temperature to the desired temperature setpoint and sends a signal to an emergency on-off valve actuator which stops the flow of heating fluid to the process if the process temperature is exceeded by an unsafe margin.

### Standards and Regulations

International standard IEC 61511 was published in 2003 to provide guidance to end-users on the application of Safety Instrumented Systems in the process industries. This standard is based on IEC 61508, a generic standard for functional safety including aspects on design, construction, and operation of electrical/electronic/programmable electronic systems.

### Safety-Related Systems

A safety-related system comprises everything (hardware, software, and human aspects) needed to perform one or more safety functions, in which failure would cause a significant increase in the safety risk for the people or environment involved.

These systems can be designed with different reliability approaches, including fail-safe, fail-soft, fail-operational, and fault-tolerant configurations depending on the application requirements.

I found search results for "control barrier function." Here are the main findings:

## Control Barrier Function in Control Theory

The search results reveal multiple types of barrier functions used in different contexts:

### Optimization and Control Theory

In constrained optimization, a barrier function is a continuous function whose value increases to infinity as its argument approaches the boundary of the feasible region of an optimization problem.(no content)Such functions are used to replace inequality constraints by a penalizing term in the objective function that is easier to handle.

### Safety and Dynamic Systems

A barrier certificate or barrier function is used to prove that a given region is forward invariant for a given ordinary differential equation or hybrid dynamical system, meaning a barrier function can be used to show that if a solution starts in a given set, then it cannot leave that set.(no content)There are different types of barrier functions: one that goes to zero at the boundary is called a zeroing barrier function, while one that goes to infinity is called a reciprocal barrier function. Zeroing barrier functions may be preferred in embedded applications as they do not create unbounded values close to the set boundary.

These concepts are fundamental in control theory for ensuring system safety and stability by constraining system behavior within specified safe regions.
